DOC.HEAD: Summary of Events
With AM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief summary of events Saturday in Panama: _2,000 U.S. soldiers arrived to reinforce the 24,000 American soldiers already in Panama. Troops met unexpectedly stiff resistance by forces loyal to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. _Panama's President Guillermo Endara named a Cabinet but declined to reveal their names because the security situation was so serious. _U.S. authorities said they had seized more than 13,000 weapons. _Panama's bishops conference urged that ``the U.S. military action end as soon as possible.'' _Nicaraguan troops surrounded the U.S. Embassy in Managua again in an effort to force U.S. soldiers searching for Noriega to end their blockade of Nicaragua's Embassy in Panama. U.S. troops continued to surround the Nicaraguan, Cuban and Libyan embassies in Panama City. _U.S. authorities said prisoners at an island penitentiary in the Pacific apparently overcame their pro-Noriega guards and radioed for help from American forces. The prison group was said to include some of the former Panamanian officers who led a failed coup Oct. 3. _The Pentagon said 24 American soldiers and 139 Panamanian soldiers have been killed. It reported 222 Americans and 95 Panamanians wounded, and two American soldiers and one civilian missing. Two civilian U.S. dependents were killed and 1,663 Panamanians detained.
